#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Below is David Shankbone 's interview with Shimon Peres , the President of Israel .
#Text=Israeli technology
#Text=One of your big initiatives in technology has been nanotechnology .
#Text=Yes .
#Text=What made you focus on nanotechnology as a sector for Israeli investment ?
#Text=Well , nanotechnology is not a vocation but a dimension .
#Text=It ’s a new dimension and it concerns all walks of life , not limited to one , from the military to the civilian .
#Text=Everywhere you turn around you can see the eventual effect of nano .
#Text=It also raises some of the most complicated moral issues because until now the human race knew how to build .
#Text=It did n’t know how to grow .
#Text=What we did is collected wood and stones and steel and glass and we built from up to down .
#Text=Structure .
#Text=Now , what is common to both building a structure is the smallest particular , the nanometer .
#Text=The minute you can manage it , you can begin to make things grow .
#Text=And that ’s a tremendous change ; it is also a tremendous dilemma for humanity .
#Text=Now actually , like on many other occasions , we discover the nano from the negative side .
#Text=The bomb .
#Text=The bomb ?
#Text=The now disused Koffler particle accelerator at the Weitzmann Institute , one of Israel 's most accomplished institutions of higher learning in the sciences .
#Text=Image : David Shankbone .
#Text=Yes .
#Text=The nuclear bomb .
#Text=The nuclear bomb was to release the hidden powers of a combination or dispersion of nanostructures .
#Text=The minute you dismantle an existing structure , then you create a lot of energy and you create new dimensions and new measurements .
#Text=I mean the size has nothing to do with power .
#Text=You can , say , take a nuclear bomb where the core is six or seven kilos of plutonium and you can destroy a city .
#Text=Why ca n’t you build a city with the six kilos ?
#Text=Same story .
#Text=And the answer is clear .
#Text=It was easier to destroy because then you do n’t have to control the nanostructure .
#Text=It ’s simple when you want explosions ; then , fission or fusion does not matter .
#Text=The minute you want to build , you have to control the nano , and for a very long time we could n’t , we were n’t able to see the nano , it is so small .
#Text=No microscope could grasp it .
#Text=The size of a nano is like 1/100th of a single hair , which is unbelievable .
#Text=Or if you want to , to compare the nanometer with the meter is to compare an orange to the globe .
#Text=Same proportion .
#Text=That ’s nothing .
#Text=And the minute they discovered the microscope , the electronic microscope that can see the nanostructure , we can begin to build .
#Text=And to build with materials and powers and combinations that we were n’t aware of .
#Text=And then you can create a lot of things , like I said , on the military side .
#Text=But it does n’t make sense to chase it in modern warfare .
#Text=It ’s not armies against armies .
#Text=It ’s strength against , the strength of a collective army against the strength of an individual terrorist .
#Text=It does not make sense to take an F-16 that costs $ 40 - 50 million and chase a terrorist .
#Text=Nano enables you to miniaturize everything .
